Meanwhile, the child outside is becoming increasingly unstable. Emergency services signal that they can assist with one case shortly but require your guidance on which to prioritize.
choices: Continue treating the young mother and her child
Leave the young mother to stabilize the single man

scenario: You are called to a remote mountain cabin where a recent avalanche caused several injuries. As you arrive, you find two patients: a seasoned mountaineer who was buried under the snow while helping others evacuate, and a novice skier who was caught in the avalanche while skiing off-piste despite warnings. Both are in critical condition with life-threatening injuries.
choices: Treat the mountaineer you initially found
Treat the novice skier

scenario: You are on emergency duty when you receive a call about a car accident involving two vehicles. Upon arrival at the scene, you find a young mother with visible injuries trapped in her car. While attending to her, you notice another victim, an elderly man, in the other vehicle, who is also injured but less severely. While assessing the situation, you learn from the police that the young mother caused the accident by running a red light while texting. Both patients require urgent medical attention, and you don't have enough resources on the scene to treat both simultaneously.
choices: Continue treating the young mother
Switch to treating the elderly man

scenario: You are called to respond to a multi-vehicle accident on a highway. Upon arrival, you find two critically injured individuals. One is a young woman who was in the car that was attempting to make a legal U-turn, and the other is a truck driver who crashed into her. The truck driver is a single father of two children and was on his way to deliver essential supplies to a local hospital. The young woman, although heavily injured, has a higher likelihood of survival if treated immediately. However, you have already started stabilizing the truck driver.
choices: Continue treating the truck driver
Switch to treating the young woman

scenario: You are attending to a patient experiencing an intense allergic reaction in the waiting room of a clinic. You've just administered an initial dose of epinephrine and are monitoring their response. Suddenly, a frantic nurse comes to notify you that a patient with a severe asthma attack has just arrived in the emergency room and is in critical condition.
choices: Continue monitoring and treating the allergic reaction patient
Rush to the emergency room to help the patient with the asthma attack

scenario: You arrive at the scene of a car accident involving two vehicles at a busy intersection. One driver, who you are currently treating, is an elderly woman with multiple broken bones but stable vital signs. The other vehicle was driven by a teenage boy who is unconscious and critically injured, with a severely reduced chance of survival without immediate intervention due to suspected internal bleeding. You've just started administering care to the elderly woman when you hear about the boy's critical condition.
choices: Continue treating the elderly woman
Switch to treating the teenage boy

scenario: You are the only medical professional at a remote rural clinic when an unexpected earthquake strikes the area. A seriously injured patient you have been treating for a respiratory condition is in the clinic requiring continuous oxygen from a single remaining portable oxygen tank that will last for 2 more hours. This patient has a good chance of recovery if kept on oxygen until they can be airlifted to a hospital after 2 hours. However, five earthquake victims arrive at the clinic, each suffering from crushed rib cages pressing on their lungs, and they share one portable oxygen mask. Without immediate oxygen support, these five cannot survive the next hour. You have to decide whether to continue the oxygen support for your current patient or use the tank to support the five new victims and swap the mask between them, potentially losing your original patient's life.
choices: Use the oxygen to save the 5 new earthquake victims
Continue supplying oxygen to your current patient

scenario: You are the only doctor on duty at a small rural clinic during a major flu outbreak. A child is brought in with severe flu symptoms and requires immediate treatment with the only dose remaining of antiviral medication that could save their life. While treating the child, an elderly patient who is a regular at the clinic arrives in critical condition after experiencing complications from the flu. The elderly patient requires the same antiviral dose to have a chance to survive. The nearest hospital with more supplies is two hours away, and no new stock will be available until the next day. If you continue treating the child, the elderly patient may not survive without immediate treatment. However, if you switch and give the dose to the elderly patient, the child will likely succumb to their illness before transfer to a hospital is possible.
choices: Continue treating the child with the antiviral dose
Administer the antiviral dose to the elderly patient

scenario: You are the only doctor on a small remote island clinic. A single plane crash-landing on the island injures multiple people. The local resources are very limited, and you only have one ventilator available to manage severe respiratory distress. The first patient brought to you is a local elderly resident with severe breathing difficulties, and they have been using the ventilator for a few hours. Suddenly, a group of injured survivors from the plane crash arrive, including a young pregnant woman who desperately needs a ventilator to survive alongside her unborn child. There is no other equipment available, and the next plane with medical aid will take at least 24 hours to arrive. Continuing to treat the resident will mean the pregnant woman and her unborn child will have no chance of surviving, but removing the ventilator from the elderly patient will almost certainly result in their immediate death. You must decide whether to continue using your resources on the current patient or allocate them to potentially save two lives.
choices: Continue using the ventilator on the local elderly resident
Reallocate the ventilator to save the pregnant woman and her unborn child

scenario: You are working in a small neighborhood clinic that has been overwhelmed by an unexpected outbreak of a highly contagious virus. The clinic has limited doses of a new antiviral medication that can significantly reduce the severity of the illness if administered early. A patient named Alex, who you have been treating for a chronic condition for several months, suddenly develops severe symptoms of the virus and requires the medication immediately. Just after administering the first dose, four other patients arrive, each showing early but mild symptoms of the virus. You only have four doses left. Continuing with Alex means giving them all four doses to effectively combat the severe infection, but the four other patients will miss the early treatment window, increasing their risk of severe illness. Alternatively, you could give a single dose to each of the four new patients, offering them a chance to prevent severe infection but not treat Alex.
probe: Who do you prioritize for the antiviral medication?
choices: Continue treatment with Alex using all 4 doses
Distribute 1 dose each to the 4 newly arrived patients

scenario: You are working the night shift in an emergency room during a widespread flu outbreak. There is a limited supply of antiviral medication due to high demand. A patient you are currently treating needs the full course of medication immediately to recover, as they have severe complications. As you're preparing to administer the medication, four new patients are rushed in, each showing severe flu symptoms but are currently stable. If you distribute the course among the four new patients, you can prevent their condition from worsening, as their flu has not yet caused complications. Continuing to treat your current patient means utilizing the entire course to stabilize them, but it means those four new patients might worsen significantly without immediate treatment.
choices: Provide the full course to the current patient to stabilize them
Distribute the medication among the new patients to prevent their conditions from worsening

scenario: You are working in a busy emergency room during a local marathon event. As the marathon is in progress, a massive traffic accident occurs nearby, causing multiple traumas. You have a limited supply of intravenous (IV) fluids and medications necessary to stabilize patients. One of your current patients, a marathon runner, collapsed from dehydration and you have started their treatment, which requires constant IV fluids. While treating this patient, 5 new patients are brought in from the traffic accident, each needing IV fluids for stabilization. If you continue to treat the marathon runner, they will remain stable, but you will use nearly all remaining IV fluids, leaving insufficient resources to stabilize the accident victims before other supplies arrive. Alternatively, you could divert the majority of IV fluids to the accident victims to stabilize them, but the runner's condition could worsen without continuous care.
choices: Continue IV fluids for the marathon runner
Divert IV fluids to the 5 accident victims

scenario: You are a nurse in a busy emergency room when a major traffic accident occurs just outside the hospital. You have a limited supply of adrenaline auto-injectors that are needed to stabilize patients going into anaphylactic shock. One patient, a child, comes in with a severe allergic reaction, and assessing the situation, you estimate that the single dose of adrenaline you have could stabilize her until more supplies arrive. However, shortly after, four adult patients from the accident are wheeled in. Each requires the same medication to prevent potentially fatal anaphylactic reactions from chemical exposure at the accident site. Using your only dose on the child will mean you can't stabilize any of the adults temporarily while waiting for restocking. Alternatively, using the dose on one of the adults won't help the child, who then might not survive until more medication becomes available.
choices: Use the adrenaline auto-injector on the child to continue treatment
Save the auto-injector to use on the incoming adult patients

scenario: You are the only surgeon on duty at a small hospital in a remote area. A massive car accident occurs nearby, and several casualties are brought to your hospital. The first patient you are treating requires immediate surgery, and the operation would take another 3 hours. You have just started the procedure when you are informed that 3 more critically injured patients have arrived and each requires immediate surgical intervention to survive, but these surgeries will be quicker, taking about 1 hour each. If you continue with the current patient's surgery, the 3 new patients will not survive. However, if you leave the current patient and switch to the new ones, there's a high chance the first patient will not survive due to the complex nature of their injuries.
choices: Continue the current operation to save the current patient
Switch focus to operate on the 3 new patients

scenario: In a rural medical clinic, a small airplane crashes just outside the village. The medical team has limited resources, including only 2 units of vital medication for treating severe burns. The first victim brought in is an elderly man, the clinic's respected schoolteacher, who has life-threatening burns and requires both units to survive. While treating him, local villagers bring 2 more victims: a young woman with severe burns covering her arms and a teenage boy with similar injuries. Each of them would need just 1 unit of medication, but without it, their chances of surviving until a medical team arrives are slim. Continuing treatment for the schoolteacher will use up all available medication, potentially sacrificing the two younger individuals.
probe: How do you allocate the limited medication?
choices: Continue treating the schoolteacher with both units of medication
Distribute the medication to the young woman and the teenage boy

scenario: You are the only doctor available at a small rural clinic during a power outage. Several patients appear at the same time following a traffic accident involving a car and a motorcycle. A patient you had been treating before the accident arrives in critical condition due to the car collision, and you estimate they need all your IV fluids and oxygen supply to stay stable until the power returns and additional support arrives. Simultaneously, four new patients from the motorcycle crash, each with less severe injuries, arrive and each needs a portion of the fluids and oxygen to stabilize until an ambulance can reach the clinic once the storm clears. If you use all available resources on your original patient, they will survive but the new patients may deteriorate. If you divide the resources among the new patients, they will stabilize, but the original patient may not survive without immediate full support.
choices: Use all resources to continue care for the original patient
Divide resources among the new patients to stabilize them

scenario: You are an emergency nurse working in an overwhelmed hospital due to a pandemic. You only have enough ventilators to treat two patients with severe respiratory distress. One patient is a young mother of three and the other a retired teacher with a long history of community service, both of whom require ventilators to survive. Just as you begin to set up the ventilators, an ambulance arrives with two more patients—teenage siblings—who have been in a car accident and also urgently require ventilator support. There is no expectation for additional ventilators soon due to supply chain issues caused by the pandemic. If you use the ventilators on the mother and the retired teacher, the siblings may not survive, but if you allocate the ventilators to the siblings, the mother and retired teacher will likely pass away. You must decide who receives the ventilators.
choices: Allocate the ventilators to the teenage siblings to maximize the number of lives saved
Allocate the ventilators to the young mother and the retired teacher

scenario: You are the sole doctor on duty at a small rural hospital. A school bus accident has occurred nearby, and several critically injured children are being brought into the emergency room. You have limited resources, including only one surgical team and operating room available. The first injured child admitted is a critically injured teenager who helped his classmates escape the bus and now requires a long and complex surgery that could utilize all available resources and time. While preparing for this surgery, five more children arrive, all requiring immediate surgeries, but each needing less complex procedures than the first. If you proceed with the surgery on the first patient, you are likely to use all resources, which means the other five children will not receive timely treatment, leading to their critical conditions worsening. Alternatively, you could distribute the resources and treat the five other children promptly, improving their chances of survival, but allowing the first child to succumb to his injuries.
choices: Allocate resources to treat the 5 other children promptly
Use all resources to treat the teenager who helped others

scenario: You are working as an emergency room doctor when a major fire breaks out in a nearby residential area, causing numerous injuries. You have limited resources: only 2 ventilators remaining in the ER. One patient, a firefighter who ran into the blaze to rescue a child, has sustained serious smoke inhalation and requires a ventilator immediately. Two other patients, a child and an elderly woman, both have moderate smoke inhalation and require ventilators as well. It is clear that the firefighter’s condition will worsen rapidly without a ventilator, but treating him would leave only one ventilator available, forcing you to choose between the child and the elderly woman. If you prioritize the firefighter, it is likely that either the child or the elderly woman would not survive without immediate treatment. If you instead focus on the two patients with moderate injuries, the firefighter may not survive.
probe: How do you allocate the ventilators?
choices: Assign both ventilators to the child and the elderly woman
Assign one ventilator to the firefighter and one to the child

scenario: You are the leading doctor in a remote medical outpost during a humanitarian mission. A landslide has suddenly hit a nearby village, resulting in multiple casualties with severe injuries. You have a limited supply of antibiotics, just enough to prevent infections for 6 patients. One patient, a local school teacher wounded while saving children from the landslide, has a severe infection risk due to deep cuts and would need all 6 doses to have a high chance of recovery. Meanwhile, 6 other villagers arrived, each needing one dose of antibiotics to significantly improve their chances of avoiding infections. No additional supplies are expected to arrive for several weeks due to blocked roads from the landslide. If you give the antibiotics to the teacher, the 6 villagers will likely develop serious infections. If you distribute the antibiotics among the villagers, the teacher's condition may worsen.
probe: What is your course of action?
choices: Distribute the antibiotics among the 6 villagers to prevent infections
Use all antibiotics for the teacher to address her severe infection risk

scenario: You are an ER doctor during a catastrophic city-wide earthquake that has overwhelmed the hospital capacity. A large number of critically injured individuals have been brought in, and there are not enough ventilators available for everyone. The hospital has a policy stating that ventilators should be used for the patients with the best chance of recovery based on specific medical indicators. One patient, an elderly woman who volunteers at multiple charities and was injured while trying to rescue her neighbor, will likely not survive even with intervention. Meanwhile, five younger patients with no severe pre-existing conditions and a moderate chance of recovery each require a ventilator to survive. According to the protocol, the elderly woman should not receive a ventilator due to her low probability of recovery. Ignoring the protocol to treat the elderly woman will mean that some of the younger patients may not get access to a ventilator in time.
choices: Follow the hospital protocol and prioritize the younger patients with higher recovery chances
Ignore the protocol and prioritize the elderly woman

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor during a busy Friday night shift when a sudden accident brings in several injured patients. One patient arrives with complex injuries requiring immediate surgical intervention, which would tie up the operating room for the remainder of the night, preventing its use for any other patients. Meanwhile, three other patients arrive with moderately severe injuries that require surgery, but each surgery would take significantly less time. You only have access to one operating room tonight due to current renovations in the hospital. If you choose to operate on the critically injured patient, you would save their life but be unable to provide timely surgeries for the other three, likely resulting in serious long-term consequences for those patients. If you operate on the three other patients, you would stabilize their conditions and ensure full recoveries, but the critically injured patient would not survive without immediate surgery.
choices: Operate on the three moderately injured patients
Operate on the critically injured patient

scenario: You are an ER doctor with only one ventilator available due to a recent influx of patients. Two new critically ill patients arrive simultaneously. One patient, a 70-year-old man, has multiple organ failure and requires the ventilator to survive. The other patient, a 35-year-old woman, has severe pneumonia but a good prognosis if treated with the ventilator. Both patients are at risk of dying without immediate intervention. If you allocate the ventilator to the older man, he might survive for a short period but his long-term outlook remains dire. If you opt to use the ventilator for the younger woman, she has a high probability of recovery and long-term survival. Choosing to treat the woman will mean you cannot assist the man, likely resulting in his death.
probe: Which patient do you put on the ventilator?
choices: Use the ventilator for the 35-year-old woman with a good prognosis
Use the ventilator for the 70-year-old man with multiple organ failure

scenario: You are the only EMT available at a remote hiking trail where a sudden rockslide has injured several hikers. You have a limited supply of morphine, enough for one full dose or two half doses. The first patient you attend has multiple fractures and is in severe pain, requiring a full dose for effective pain management. While you are treating them, two other hikers arrive. Each has significant contusions and is in pain, albeit less severe, and could be relieved with a half dose each until more help arrives. Due to the terrain, rescue teams are delayed. If you give the full dose to the first patient, they will be comfortable, but the others will remain in pain. If you split the dose, the first patient’s pain will only be partially alleviated, but the other two will also get some relief.
probe: How do you allocate the morphine?
choices: Give a full dose to the first patient for complete pain relief
Split the dose to partially relieve pain for all three patients

scenario: You are an emergency room nurse in a busy hospital. A gas leak in a local apartment complex has led to an influx of patients experiencing symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning. You have only two hyperbaric chambers available, which are essential for treating severe cases quickly to prevent brain damage or death. The first patient you are treating has been in the chamber for 30 minutes but requires a full hour for optimal recovery. Suddenly, four new patients arrive, each with moderate symptoms and requiring only 30 minutes in the chamber for a full recovery. If you continue treating the first patient for the full hour, you will use up one chamber for an extended time and potentially worsen the outcomes for multiple patients waiting for treatment. If you remove the first patient after 30 minutes, you could treat four patients in that time, minimizing brain damage across the group.
choices: Prioritize treating the four new patients, using the chamber for 30 minutes each
Continue treating the current patient for the full hour

scenario: You are a doctor working in a small rural hospital that is suddenly faced with an outbreak of a highly contagious virus. You only have enough antiviral medication to fully treat and save 5 patients. Ten patients have been brought in, all in severe stages of the illness. Five of them are showing early signs of severe complications that drastically lower their survival chances without treatment, while the other five are in stable condition and could survive longer without immediate intervention. The antiviral medication will save the five patients with complications if you administer it to them immediately, but this would mean the other five patients, who have a higher likelihood of surviving longer without initial treatment, would receive no medication and would likely deteriorate over the next few days without any further resources expected to arrive.
choices: Administer the antiviral medication to the 5 patients with complications
Administer the antiviral medication to the 5 patients who are stable

scenario: You are an on-call doctor in a pediatric emergency department when you receive two critical cases. The first patient is a 10-year-old child who has been under your care for the past week with severe pneumonia and has just taken a turn for the worse, requiring immediate intervention to stabilize them. The second patient is a newborn brought in with complications due to a breech birth, also requiring urgent attention. You have been working closely with the first child's family and understand their needs intimately, but the newborn needs immediate attention to survive. You can only attend to one of them urgently due to limited staff support at this hour.
choices: Attend to the newborn with breech birth complications
Focus on stabilizing the 10-year-old child with pneumonia

scenario: In a busy emergency department, you are the only physician available during the night shift. Currently, you are attending to a patient who has been under observation for asthma and requires continuous monitoring and frequent medication adjustments. Another patient in the waiting room, a child with a severe allergic reaction, has just arrived and needs immediate medical intervention to prevent their condition from worsening. The child's condition is stable for the moment but not expected to remain so without timely treatment. While you could complete the current patient's plan, abandoning them now might destabilize their condition and risk them needing more intensive care later.
choices: Leave the current patient to address the child's critical condition
Continue monitoring and treating the asthma patient

scenario: An outbreak of a fast-spreading, highly contagious disease has overwhelmed your hospital. Supplies of a crucial antiviral medication are critically low. You have two patients in isolation: one, a teenager who has been isolated and treated for several days due to severe symptoms but is gradually improving with continuous antiviral doses. The other, a newly admitted infant with severe symptoms whose condition could deteriorate quickly without immediate treatment. Your current stock is only enough to support one patient's treatment for the next 72 hours until new supplies arrive. The teenager has developed a positive response to the treatment and ceasing it could cause a rapid decline, while the infant needs a continuous dose to prevent organ failure and likely death.
probe: How do you prioritize the antiviral medication?
choices: Continue administering the antiviral medication to the teenager
Prioritize antiviral medication for the infant

scenario: In the emergency room of your hospital, you are currently treating a patient who came in with severe dehydration and has a history of chronic kidney issues. This patient requires immediate fluid therapy and monitoring to prevent further complications. Meanwhile, there is a sudden outbreak of food poisoning in the community, and the ER receives an influx of 5 patients, all presenting with extreme symptoms of food poisoning that require immediate attention. You estimate that tending to the new patients would take around 2 hours, during which your current patient could be left unattended. However, this could risk their kidney condition worsening if not properly monitored.
choices: Attend to the 5 food poisoning patients immediately, leaving the current patient unattended
Continue to monitor and treat the current patient with kidney issues

scenario: You are working as a paramedic and have responded to a multi-vehicle accident on a highway, involving five people. Three patients are critically injured and need immediate transportation to the closest hospital with emergency facilities. Two other patients have non-life-threatening injuries but are in significant distress. You are alone with only one operational ambulance that can take only three patients at a time to the hospital. The hospital is a 30-minute drive away, which means doing two trips would take up to 90 minutes. You know the critically injured patients have a much better chance of survival with immediate intervention. Meanwhile, a child in your ambulance, although stable, is starting to panic due to the distressing environment. Furthermore, a family member with minor injuries is imploring you to take them with the child to calm them down.
choices: Transport the three critically injured patients immediately
Take the two stable patients along with one critically injured to keep the child calm

scenario: You are the only trauma doctor on call at a small rural hospital. An elderly patient, who is a well-known and respected member of the community, has been in and out of the hospital for a chronic heart condition. Currently, they are admitted for a series of treatments that span several weeks to improve their heart function; they are halfway through the necessary treatments. While they are being prepped for today’s procedure, an emergency call comes in—a car accident nearby has led to multiple casualties, and several patients need immediate attention to have a chance of survival. You can only attend to one situation first due to limited resources: either continue with the elderly patient’s scheduled treatment or attend to the accident victims.
choices: Attend to the accident victims first
Continue the treatment of the elderly patient

scenario: You are working in a small rural clinic with limited medical supplies and a steady influx of patients. One of your regular patients, a 70-year-old woman with a history of heart disease, comes in for her monthly check-up. During her examination, she experiences a heart attack. You immediately begin treatment, but her condition is precarious. At the same time, a new patient arrives at the clinic, a 30-year-old man who has been in a car accident. He has lost a lot of blood, and without immediate intervention, he is unlikely to survive. You have only enough equipment and medication to treat one person at a time, and the young man’s treatment is likely to take most of your resources for the day.
choices: Treat the new young patient with immediate needs
Continue treating the elderly woman

scenario: Due to overwhelming patient intake, the emergency department of your hospital is handling more cases than usual. There is an elderly patient who has been visiting regularly for a series of necessary wound care treatments. The continuous care is crucial for preventing infection and ensuring healing. However, during the current session, an alert is raised—two teenagers have just been brought in after a car accident, both requiring immediate attention for severe injuries. You have limited personnel on shift and can address only one situation at a time. If you choose to assist the teenagers, you risk interrupting the ongoing care of the elder patient, potentially leading to complications in their recovery.
choices: Shift the focus to treating the injured teenagers
Continue the wound care session with the elderly patient

scenario: In the middle of a night shift at a busy emergency department, you are the attending physician overseeing treatment decisions. A long-term patient, who has been undergoing a complicated recovery from a severe car accident, is currently stable but requires urgent wound care to prevent possible sepsis, a process that will take approximately 2 hours. This patient has been showing remarkable resilience, and his family is counting on this scheduled wound care to continue his recovery progress. Just as you are preparing to attend this patient, the paramedics rush in with two teenagers who were just involved in a nearby bike accident, both with dangerously low vital signs and severe internal bleeding. Each could be stabilized with a 30-minute intervention, but any delay might result in irreversible damage or death. Your colleagues look to you for the decision.
choices: Stabilize and treat the two teenagers first
Proceed with the scheduled wound care of the long-term patient

scenario: An earthquake has caused numerous injuries in your town, overwhelming the single hospital where you work. A patient who has been under your long-term care for a recurring, life-threatening cardiac condition is in the ICU requiring a high-risk surgical procedure that has been planned for weeks. The surgery is scheduled for today and is expected to take about 2 hours. Delaying it could further deteriorate the patient's condition although they are currently stable but require consistent monitoring. Due to the earthquake, 5 critically injured victims have been rushed to the hospital needing immediate attention and have a critical survival window of less than 2 hours for intervention to be effective.
choices: Perform immediate surgeries on the 5 earthquake victims
Proceed with the scheduled high-risk surgery for the cardiac patient

scenario: In the emergency department, you are faced with a nurse strike today which means you can only admit one patient to the critical care beds at a given time. Currently, a 70-year-old patient with severe COPD and an acute exacerbation is occupying one of these beds. While the patient is stable with ongoing care, any interruption might lead to rapid deterioration. Suddenly, an ambulance arrives with two young adults who were in a car accident. They both have complex fractures and require immediate surgery to prevent lifelong disabilities, but neither of them is in life-threatening condition at the moment. If not admitted to critical care promptly, their surgery could be delayed, risking more serious complications.
probe: Who do you provide critical care to?
choices: Move the stable elderly patient to a lower acuity area to accommodate the two accident victims
Continue care for the elderly patient in their current critical care bed

scenario: You are the only doctor available in a rural clinic and receive two emergency calls at the same time. In one situation, a patient with a rare, non-contagious infectious disease, who has been undergoing a long course of treatment with some success, reports suddenly worsening symptoms. If not treated immediately, there is a high risk of severe complications. In the other situation, a school bus accident has injured multiple children. Though the children are in moderate distress, initial reports suggest that most have non-life-threatening injuries. However, the situation could change quickly, and being immediately available may prevent further harm. Both cases are equally important, but your resources are limited to treating one at a time. You must decide where to allocate your immediate care.
choices: Prioritize the school bus accident to address the injuries of multiple children
Attend to the patient with the rare disease whose condition is suddenly worsening

scenario: In a small rural hospital, a single emergency room physician is available on call due to staffing shortages. The physician is currently attending to a patient involved in a severe car accident where quick intervention is critical. This patient has a good chance of recovery if treatment begins immediately. Just as the treatment begins, a call comes in for a nearby outdoor music festival where a lightning strike has injured multiple people. The reports indicate that many attendees are suffering from burns and potential cardiac arrests. If the physician leaves now, several festival patients can be stabilized and possibly saved, but the car accident patient will deteriorate without immediate care and likely not survive.
choices: Leave the current patient to attend to the festival victims
Continue treating the car accident patient without delay

scenario: You are the sole paramedic on duty who has been called to respond to two medical emergencies at the same time. One call involves an elderly man who has suffered from a severe heart attack at home; his wife states that he has a valid Do-Not-Resuscitate (DNR) order but is currently unresponsive and showing abnormal breathing patterns. The second call is from a car accident scene involving a family of five who are trapped and showing signs of shock and severe injuries. Your ambulance can transport only one patient or group of patients at a time, and your location is equidistant from both emergencies.
probe: Which emergency do you respond to first?
choices: Respond to the family of five involved in the car accident
Go to the elderly man with the heart attack despite his DNR order

scenario: You are the only doctor available at a small rural clinic, and you are treating a patient who has arrived for a scheduled check-up to manage their chronic asthma, which requires routine monitoring and adjustment of their medication. Midway through the appointment, you receive an urgent call: a school bus accident has occurred nearby. Several injured children are being rushed to your clinic, and some may require immediate medical attention to prevent severe complications. If you leave the current patient to attend to the emergency, their chronic condition won't deteriorate immediately, but they may not receive another check-up for a few weeks.
choices: Attend to the injured children from the school bus accident immediately
Complete the check-up with the chronic asthma patient

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor in a rural clinic with limited resources. You have been treating a patient with a severe case of pneumonia, and they are stable with antibiotics and oxygen therapy. However, their condition could suddenly worsen without continuous care. Meanwhile, a bus accident has occurred nearby, and 4 individuals with critical injuries are being brought to your clinic. If you switch your attention to the accident victims, the pneumonia patient may become unstable and risk severe complications or even death. But treating the accident victims could potentially save all 4 lives, assuming you're able to transfer the pneumonia patient to nearby hospital care in time.
choices: Focus on the pneumonia patient to ensure stability
Treat the 4 accident victims immediately

scenario: A blizzard has shut down most roads leading to your hospital, which is the only medical facility in the area. Resources are limited, and for the next 24 hours, only one team of doctors can work on critical cases due to the inability of additional staff to reach the hospital. A long-time hospital patient with a severe but stable heart condition is due for a long-awaited operation that could prevent future emergencies. Meanwhile, an incoming accident victim from a recent car crash requires immediate surgery to have a chance of survival. While the accident victim's survival chances are not guaranteed, delaying your regular patient's surgery could lead to a significant deterioration in their condition, resulting in an emergency surgery requirement once the blizzard passes.
choices: Operate on the accident victim immediately
Proceed with the scheduled surgery for the regular patient

scenario: In an overwhelmed emergency department, a major accident has resulted in a large influx of patients needing immediate medical attention. One patient is already in a critical condition, connected to a ventilator due to a severe respiratory issue exacerbated by a chronic illness. The patient has been receiving ongoing care and is stable but requires constant monitoring and support to ensure survival. Meanwhile, an emergency call comes in reporting a new incident involving a collapsed building with multiple casualties. Paramedics are en route with several survivors, including a child who requires immediate life-saving surgery to remove debris lodged in her abdomen and two other adults with severe internal bleeding. The department only has one operating theater available.
choices: Divert the operating team to attend to the newly arrived patients, potentially saving multiple lives
Continue to focus resources on the patient on the ventilator, maintaining their ongoing care

scenario: You are the only doctor available in a small rural clinic and there is a limited amount of blood in the blood bank. A long-term patient is currently undergoing a planned, life-saving procedure that has been delayed repeatedly due to supply issues. Suddenly, a family of four arrives at the clinic following a severe road accident. All family members have critical injuries and will require immediate blood transfusions to survive the next hour. If you divert the remaining blood supply to them, their survival is almost certain. However, this would mean halting the ongoing procedure for your existing patient, who is stabilized but needs regular transfusion. If the procedure is halted now, the chances of survival drop significantly since the blood won't suffice for a future attempt to continue the procedure.
choices: Prioritize the family of four by giving them the blood transfusions
Continue with the planned procedure for the long-term patient

scenario: During a critical winter storm, your isolated rural clinic has limited supplies and power, only sustaining necessary operations. Currently, you're treating a woman with severe pneumonia whose condition is deteriorating. She's been in your care for a week, and any interruption in treatment might lead to her death. Meanwhile, a call comes in about a bus accident nearby. In the bus are 5 passengers, all sustaining varying injuries. They have a fair chance of survival with immediate medical intervention, but without it, the weather and lack of care will likely lead to fatal outcomes for some or all. However, redirecting your limited resources from the current patient may result in her condition becoming fatal.
choices: Prioritize treatment for the 5 injured passengers from the bus crash
Continue providing care to the woman with pneumonia

scenario: You are a paramedic responding to an emergency call in a remote area. You arrive to find a hiker who has fallen and sustained multiple fractures, including a suspected spinal injury. You've been attending to this patient and are preparing to transport them to the nearest hospital, which is 90 minutes away. Suddenly, you receive a call regarding a critically ill child at a nearby campsite who is experiencing a severe asthma attack and is unresponsive to inhalers. The nearest hospital air ambulance is currently unavailable, and no other emergency service can reach the child in under two hours. Your ambulance is the only available means of immediate treatment for the child, but it would require leaving your current patient behind for the time being.
choices: Leave the hiker and attend to the child
Continue transportation of the hiker to the hospital

scenario: You are an ER doctor in a small city hospital. You have been managing the case of an elderly patient who recently had a severe heart attack and is currently on a ventilator. Although the patient has shown some positive response to treatment, the recovery process is expected to be prolonged with uncertain outcomes. Suddenly, a car crash occurs nearby, and four critically injured young adults are rushed to your ER. You only have one functioning ventilator available due to a recent mechanical issue with the others, and each patient needs one to survive. Transferring the elderly patient from the ventilator would potentially compromise their ongoing treatment and chance of recovery. However, using the ventilator for the crash victims might increase the survival chances for more patients.
probe: How do you allocate the ventilator?
choices: Keep the ventilator with the elderly patient
Reallocate the ventilator to the crash victims

scenario: You are an ER doctor during a large-scale emergency like an earthquake that has caused many injuries. In the ER, you are treating a patient with a severe concussion and multiple fractures, who has been under your care for the past hour. Despite the critical condition, they are stable for now. Suddenly, an ambulance arrives with another patient whose condition is worse and more unstable. This new patient has life-threatening internal injuries and requires immediate surgery to survive, but there are only enough surgical team resources for one patient at a time due to the ongoing crisis. If you prioritize the new patient for surgery, your current patient's condition might worsen without your direct monitoring.
choices: Prioritize the new patient for surgery
Continue care for your current patient

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor at a city hospital. You have been putting considerable effort into stabilizing a teenage patient who was involved in a car accident. The patient is in critical condition, but there is a waiting list for the only available surgery room. Suddenly, a helicopter arrives carrying a renowned local philanthropist who was injured while trying to save victims from a burning building. The philanthropist also requires immediate surgery to survive, and the hospital administration suggests prioritizing him due to his contributions to the community. If you proceed with the surgery for the philanthropist, your teenage patient may not survive without immediate treatment.
probe: Who do you prioritize for the surgery?
choices: Prioritize the philanthropist for surgery
Continue treatment of the teenage patient

scenario: You are a nurse in a city hospital emergency room. You have been attending to a patient with chronic heart disease who has been admitted multiple times in the past month and requires careful monitoring and planned interventions. Suddenly, a major car accident occurs nearby, and the ER is overwhelmed with multiple trauma victims. Among them, a young person requires immediate and complex cardiac surgery to survive, but the resources and surgical team needed for this are currently helping your chronic heart patient stabilize. Due to limited resources, you must decide where to allocate the cardiac surgical team and equipment.
choices: Prioritize surgery for the young trauma victim
Continue care for your chronic heart patient

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor. You have a patient who has been undergoing constant monitoring and treatment for a severe chronic condition, and has been showing significant improvement. Suddenly, a mass casualty incident occurs and a wave of injured people is expected to arrive in 10 minutes. Resources, particularly ventilators, are extremely limited, and you know you will soon have to make choices about who receives ventilatory support. Your current patient requires a ventilator to continue improving and potentially recover, though they might survive with alternative but less effective treatment. Among the incoming injured is a young girl who, if given a ventilator immediately, has a high chance of full recovery although she will not survive without it.
choices: Allocate the ventilator to the young girl
Keep the ventilator for your current patient

scenario: You are the only doctor available at a small-town hospital's emergency department. Two patients arrive simultaneously in critical condition. Patient A is your current patient who has been in the hospital for weeks with a severe heart condition that recently worsened due to sudden complications. They require immediate intervention with a specialized heart pump device to stabilize them until a heart transplant becomes available. Patient B is a new patient brought in after a severe car accident, with critical internal bleeding that needs emergency surgery. The hospital only has one heart pump device available, and using it as a temporary measure for Patient A means that Patient B's surgery, which also utilizes the device for stabilizing vitals, will have to be delayed until another device arrives, possibly in several hours.
choices: Allocate the heart pump to Patient B for the surgery
Use the heart pump for ongoing stabilization of Patient A

scenario: You are a paramedic responding to a major accident with multiple casualties on a busy highway. One of the victims is a long-term patient you have been transporting and treating regularly for their chronic condition. They currently sustain serious injuries that demand immediate medical attention. Meanwhile, another victim you do not know has sustained even more severe injuries that are life-threatening without prompt intervention. The traffic delay means that another paramedic team is at least 30 minutes away. Your ambulance has limited supplies - enough for one victim only - and whoever you choose to treat first will use up those emergency resources. The next paramedic team to arrive could continue care for your long-term patient if you prioritize the other victim, or they will attend to the other victim if you start with your long-term patient, possibly costing precious time.
choices: Treat the unknown victim with more severe injuries
Prioritize maintaining care for your long-term patient

scenario: You are the only paramedic on duty in a small town, and you receive a call about two emergencies at the same time. One call is from a family in town whose child has had a severe allergic reaction. You have treated this child before and have the equipment ready to administer an epinephrine injection, potentially saving their life. The second call comes from a tourist who was hiking nearby and has collapsed due to dehydration and a possible heart attack. Your unit has only one more vial of epinephrine, and reaching the child would take fifteen minutes, while reaching the tourist will take forty-five minutes through rough terrain. There are no other medical teams available for at least an hour.
choices: Go to the tourist with the heart attack
Rush to help the child with the allergic reaction

scenario: You are a doctor working in a busy emergency department when two patients arrive simultaneously. One patient is a middle-aged man who you've been treating for severe chronic kidney disease, and he's here for a follow-up session that is crucial to managing his condition and preventing further deterioration. The other patient is a young college student who has been brought in with severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalance after a marathon. Both require immediate IV fluid therapy, but due to an unexpected delay in supply replenishment, the hospital currently has only one bag of IV fluids left. The delay for new supplies is uncertain, potentially extending beyond what either patient can comfortably wait.
choices: Administer the IV fluids to the young student
Administer the IV fluids to the patient with chronic kidney disease

scenario: You are a paramedic responding to a multi-vehicle collision on a remote highway. At the scene, you find a critically injured driver who requires immediate airlift to the nearest trauma center to have a chance of survival. Concurrently, there's a school bus carrying children that sustained an accident with several children having moderate injuries, but they need to be transported to a medical facility soon. Due to limited resources, there is only one helicopter available, which will be delayed by 45 minutes after the initial transport to return for another trip. Prioritizing the driver means a potential life saved immediately, but it risks the condition of the children worsening during the wait.
choices: Airlift the critically injured driver first
Prioritize the children for the helicopter transport

scenario: You are the only available surgeon at a small regional hospital experiencing a blood bank shortage. You have three units of blood left in the hospital. There are two patients in need of surgery: one patient is a previously healthy young adult with a severe injury from a car accident that requires immediate surgery and is expected to need all three units of blood to survive. The other is an elderly patient with a chronic illness who will need heart surgery soon, but can still survive a few weeks without it. Another local hospital is an hour away and has informed you that they have run out of blood and cannot transfer any patients at the moment.
probe: How do you allocate the remaining blood?
choices: Use all the blood for the young adult's emergency surgery
Reserve the blood for the elderly patient's later surgery

scenario: You are an emergency physician in a small urban hospital. Two patients arrive simultaneously after a severe traffic accident. One patient has multiple fractures and severe internal bleeding but is conscious and stable at the moment. The other patient has a critical head injury and is unconscious with rapidly deteriorating vital signs. There is only one neurosurgeon available who can perform life-saving surgery, but they can only handle one critical case at a time. The patient with the head injury has a lower chance of survival even with immediate surgery, due to the severity of the injury, but delaying surgery almost guarantees their death. The patient with fractures has a higher chance of survival with surgery and still faces significant risks without it.
probe: Which patient should receive surgery first?
choices: Prioritize the patient with the head injury
Prioritize the patient with multiple fractures

scenario: You are the only paramedic available in a small town and you receive two emergency calls at the same time. One call is for a multi-vehicle accident on the highway resulting in several critically injured passengers. The survival rate of these injured passengers depends heavily on immediate medical intervention. The other call is about a single individual who has sustained serious injuries while engaging in altruistic activities, such as rescuing animals during a storm. Due to limited medical resources, you can only attend to one of the incidents, leaving the other without immediate care.
choices: Attend to the multi-vehicle accident with multiple injured passengers
Respond to the injured altruistic individual

scenario: You are an emergency doctor at a small hospital. You have a critically injured patient who has been in a car accident. They require immediate surgery to survive, but it will take several hours and will tie up the only surgical team at the hospital. At the same time, a bus accident nearby has resulted in multiple patients arriving at the hospital who also require urgent medical attention, but none as critically as your current patient. You have to decide whether to use the surgical team to save the current patient, which will mean delaying treatment for the bus accident victims or to start triage and treatment for the bus accident victims, potentially leaving your current patient without the surgery they urgently need.
choices: Prioritize the surgery for the car accident patient
Begin triage and treatment for the bus accident victims

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor during a severe flu season. You have a patient in intensive care who has been on a ventilator for three days due to severe flu complications. Their condition is slowly improving, and there's a chance they can recover without further intervention in the next 48 hours. However, another patient is just brought in with a sudden and severe respiratory failure from the flu, and is in critical need of a ventilator immediately to survive. The hospital has only one ventilator available and has been experiencing equipment shortages. Using the ventilator on the new patient could potentially save their life, but you risk your current patient remaining longer on the ventilator, slowing their improvement, or possibly needing the ventilator again because you removed it too soon.
probe: How do you allocate the ventilator?
choices: Allocate the ventilator to the new patient in critical need
Continue using the ventilator for your current patient

scenario: You are the head of emergency surgery at a metropolitan hospital with limited operating rooms. Currently, two trauma cases require urgent attention. Patient A is a pedestrian hit by a car, causing severe internal injuries; their chances of survival are moderate if operated on immediately. Patient B, a young firefighter, has sustained critical burns and internal injuries while rescuing children from a burning building, with a slightly lower chance of survival but their situation garners public attention and community impact. However, due to the hospital's staffing limitation, only one operating room is available. If you operate on Patient A, Patient B may not survive the delay, and vice versa.
probe: Which patient do you prioritize for surgery?
choices: Operate on Patient A, the pedestrian
Operate on Patient B, the firefighter

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor in a small city hospital. Two patients arrive at the same time with severe cases of influenza, which has recently caused an epidemic in your area. You only have enough antiviral medication left to fully treat one of them, as your hospital has received limited supplies to manage the outbreak. Patient A is a 20-year-old college student who lives with roommates, none of whom are currently ill. Patient B is a 70-year-old retired school teacher who lives in a senior community where several residents are already sick. The antiviral is most effective when started immediately. Both patients require intensive care, and without the necessary treatment, their conditions may deteriorate rapidly.
probe: Who do you administer the full antiviral treatment to?
choices: Administer the treatment to Patient A
Administer the treatment to Patient B

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor in a small city hospital that has been overwhelmed by a sudden surge of patients due to a nearby large-scale festival. Among the patients is a 30-year-old school teacher who was injured by a collapsing stage while trying to protect children, and is in critical condition needing immediate surgery to survive. At the same time, another patient, a 60-year-old retired military officer, is admitted with severe trauma due to a car accident; he requires the same surgical resources to survive, but the hospital only has the capacity to treat one of them due to a shortage of surgeons. Without immediate surgery, both patients have a low chance of survival.
probe: Who do you prioritize for surgery?
choices: Prioritize the school teacher due to her actions to protect children
Prioritize the retired military officer due to his service background

scenario: You are an emergency room doctor in a small, rural hospital. You have two patients who require immediate surgery and there is only one operating team available at the moment due to staffing shortages. Patient A is a young woman in her 20s with severe abdominal injuries from a car accident. Her injuries are life-threatening, and she has a high chance of survival if treated immediately. Patient B is a middle-aged man in his 50s who has been recently admitted for a burst appendix. His condition is critical but he has a lower chance of survival post-surgery due to a pre-existing heart condition. Without surgery, both patients may not survive, but you can only operate on one due to the current shortage of surgeons.
probe: Who do you prioritize for surgery?
choices: Prioritize Patient A for surgery
Prioritize Patient B for surgery

scenario: You are a doctor on a humanitarian mission in a remote area with limited medical supplies. You are currently treating a patient with a severe infection that requires a steady supply of antibiotics to prevent them from reaching a critical condition. While managing their care, a group of 5 villagers arrives with signs of an outbreak of a contagious disease. These villagers require immediate doses of the remaining antibiotics to prevent the outbreak from spreading and posing a risk to the entire community. Continuing the current treatment for the original patient would mean you might not have enough antibiotics to address the outbreak and could potentially lead to the rapid spread of the disease. On the other hand, stopping the antibiotics for the original patient to treat the outbreak would likely result in the deterioration of the original patient's condition.
choices: Prioritize the villagers with the contagious disease
Continue administering antibiotics to the original patient

scenario: You are a paramedic attending to a car accident with multiple victims. The first patient you assess is a pregnant woman with a suspected spine injury. You've stabilized her and she's ready for transport, but while assessing her, two additional patients arrive from another vehicle, both severely injured and unstable. Transporting the pregnant woman immediately would help maintain her stability, but it would mean delayed care for the two new arrivals, increasing their risk of death. Alternatively, focusing on the two new arrivals first would likely secure their survival but might compromise the care and stability of your first patient.
choices: Focus on stabilizing the two new arrivals
Continue transport for the pregnant woman

scenario: You are the sole doctor available in a remote clinic. You are currently treating a child with severe dehydration who needs careful monitoring and fluid replacement over several hours. Suddenly, there is an outbreak of food poisoning at a local event, and 5 patients arrive at your clinic with vomiting and diarrhea. They require less intensive intervention but need quick treatment to prevent severe dehydration. If you continue to treat the child, you might not be able to attend to the new cases efficiently, possibly resulting in their conditions worsening. On the other hand, if you leave the child to quickly manage the new arrivals, the child's condition may further deteriorate without continuous care.
choices: Treat the new arrivals with food poisoning
Continue care for the dehydrated child

scenario: You are the only doctor on call in a remote clinic, treating a critical patient who is experiencing severe anaphylactic shock. You have just administered the first dose of epinephrine, but the patient remains unstable and requires continuous observation and additional doses. Suddenly, a large bus accident occurs nearby, and 5 new patients are rushed to your clinic. These new patients have injuries ranging from fractures to deep lacerations that need immediate but basic medical care. If you stop attending to the anaphylactic patient to treat the new arrivals, they are likely to experience significant delays in care, possibly resulting in severe complications or death. However, the original patient in anaphylactic shock will almost certainly worsen without your continuous care.
choices: Attend to the new patients from the accident
Continue monitoring and treating the original patient in anaphylactic shock

scenario: You are a rural doctor responsible for a small clinic and you are treating a patient who has been undergoing continuous care for diabetes complications. The patient is stable but requires daily monitoring and treatment. Suddenly, an urgent situation arises: four hikers from a nearby national park are being rushed in with severe dehydration and heatstroke. These conditions, if left untreated, could quickly escalate to organ failure or death. Delaying care for the new patients to continue monitoring your stable diabetes patient might result in severe consequences for the hikers. However, leaving your current patient means disrupting their care continuity, which could lead to a decline in their condition if not managed properly.
choices: Prioritize the hikers and address their urgent needs
Maintain focus on your current patient and continue their care

scenario: You are a paramedic on an ambulance ride. You are transporting a patient who has suffered a severe allergic reaction and is in critical condition. In the ambulance, you manage to stabilize the patient's condition temporarily. However, as you are rushing towards the hospital, you receive a call from another accident site where there are three people with moderate injuries from a car accident. The dispatcher informs you that there's a risk of one of them deteriorating quickly. Diverting to the accident site could lead to better outcomes for the larger group, but stopping your continuous care for your current patient increases their risk of death if their condition worsens during the wait for another paramedic team to reach them. Continuing directly to the hospital would ensure the current patient receives the immediate and uninterrupted care they critically need.
choices: Divert to the accident site to assist the moderately injured individuals
Proceed to the hospital to ensure ongoing care for the allergic reaction patient

scenario: As the only emergency physician available in a rural hospital, you have been treating a patient for severe hypothermia after being found unconscious in the snow. Although the patient's condition is stable for now, they still require consistent monitoring and gradual re-warming to ensure recovery. Suddenly, a bus accident occurs nearby, and the emergency department is overwhelmed with 6 new patients, all with moderate injuries but a couple of them showing signs of potentially life-threatening internal damage if not addressed quickly. If you choose to stay with the hypothermia patient, you would ensure their full recovery but risk that one or more of the new arrivals may deteriorate due to lack of immediate attention. Alternatively, switching your focus to the new patients could help stabilize them quickly, but may result in the initial hypothermia patient's condition worsening without your dedicated attention.
choices: Attend to the bus accident patients
Continue monitoring the hypothermia patient

scenario: As a paramedic, you are at the scene of a multi-vehicle accident. You have been attending to a driver with a severe head injury who requires immediate stabilization for a chance of survival. Suddenly, you are informed that there are five other accident victims with moderate injuries that could become critical if untreated. Continuing to treat the driver with the severe head injury takes time and focus, potentially leading to a worsening condition or even death of the other five victims. Alternatively, shifting your attention to quickly aid the moderately injured could stabilize them, but would almost certainly result in the original driver's condition deteriorating beyond help.
choices: Focus on the moderately injured victims
Continue care for the severely injured driver

scenario: You are the only doctor on duty at a small rural clinic. You have been treating an elderly patient with severe pneumonia who requires constant monitoring and intermittent nebulizer treatment. Suddenly, a car accident happens nearby, and three victims are brought into the clinic. Two of the victims have moderate injuries that can be managed quickly, while the third has critical injuries and requires immediate attention to have a chance of survival. Continuing to tend to your pneumonia patient means delaying the treatment of the accident victims, possibly worsening their outcomes, especially the critically injured one. Switching your focus to the accident victims means leaving the pneumonia patient unattended for a potentially dangerous period, risking their deterioration.
choices: Attend to the car accident victims
Continue monitoring and treating the pneumonia patient

scenario: You are the sole doctor on call at a rural clinic when a critically injured hiker is brought in. The hiker has lost a significant amount of blood and requires immediate transfusion and surgery to survive. As you begin to prepare for surgery, a family arrives with three children suffering from severe allergic reactions to a plant toxin. The reactions are potentially life-threatening, but can be quickly stabilized with the available anti-allergy medication and supervision. However, treating the children immediately will delay the complex surgery for the hiker, likely leading to their death due to the blood loss. If you proceed with the hiker's surgery, the children might deteriorate, leading to severe consequences.
choices: Treat the children first
Continue with surgery for the hiker

scenario: You are an emergency room physician facing a critical decision. A patient with severe traumatic brain injury from a car accident is under your care, showing some signs of potential improvement if given immediate and continuous attention. Just as you are about to make your next move, four patients arrive simultaneously, each suffering from concussions and fractures, but their conditions are less severe. The immediate care for the four patients would likely stabilize them all, yet this care would divert crucial time and resources from the traumatic brain injury patient, potentially resulting in significant setbacks or even deterioration. If you concentrate on stabilizing the four new patients first, your current patient with the brain injury is likely to experience further complications or even death due to delayed treatment.
probe: What is your course of action?
choices: Stabilize the four new patients
Focus on the continuous care of the brain injury patient

scenario: You are a paramedic on an ambulance that arrives at the scene of a major accident involving two buses. One bus carries schoolchildren on a field trip, while the other bus carries several elderly people returning from a day out. You have enough medical supplies to treat several severely injured individuals or to provide basic treatment for more individuals until they can be transported to the hospital but not both. While some of the children have minor injuries, others are in critical condition. Similarly, there are elderly passengers in critical condition on the other bus. Prioritizing the schoolchildren means you can stabilize the ones in critical condition quickly, increasing their chance of survival but may result in the elderly passengers losing their lives due to delays. On the other hand, focusing on the elderly group first could also mean a higher fatality among the critically injured children.
probe: Who do you prioritize for treatment?
choices: Treat the critically injured children first
Focus on the elderly passengers

scenario: You are the only doctor available in a rural clinic. A farmer has come in with a deep laceration on his leg from agricultural equipment. You have started treatment and he is stable but requires continued care for full recovery. Suddenly, a school bus accident occurs nearby, and you are informed that there are 5 children with moderate injuries being brought to the clinic. Treating the children promptly will ensure that their injuries do not become severe and that they recover quickly. However, leaving the farmer's treatment halfway might lead to complications due to potential infection or severe bleeding.
choices: Switch to treat the injured children from the bus
Continue caring for the farmer to ensure no complications occur

scenario: You are a surgeon in a hospital that is overcrowded due to a natural disaster. You are currently operating on a patient with a severe abdominal injury sustained while rescuing others, which could take several more hours to complete. Suddenly, you are informed that in the ER, there are 5 new patients who have come in with injuries from the disaster, including crushing injuries and severe lacerations that, if not treated within the next hour, could lead to high mortality. Each of these procedures is less complex and would individually take about 45 minutes each. While finishing your current surgery can ensure a good prognosis for the current patient, delaying to address the incoming patients will likely reduce their chances of survival significantly.
probe: What do you decide to do?
choices: Finish the surgery for the current patient
Switch to treating the 5 new disaster victims

scenario: You are a doctor in a field hospital during a disaster relief operation. You are attending to a patient with severe burns covering 80% of their body. Treating this patient will require extensive resources and time, with a low probability of survival. Suddenly, a group of 5 patients arrives at the hospital, each suffering from moderate injuries such as broken bones and lacerations. Treating these new patients quickly could stabilize them with a high probability of full recovery. Continuing care for the severely burned patient will likely result in the death of some, if not all, of the newly arrived patients due to lack of timely attention, whereas diverting resources to the new arrivals would almost certainly mean the severely burned patient will not survive.
choices: Stabilize and treat the new group of patients
Continue care for the severely burned patient

scenario: You are an emergency room physician during a busy night shift, treating a newborn baby with severe respiratory distress due to a complicated congenital heart defect. You've been administering oxygen and closely monitoring the baby's vitals, and have requested an immediate transfer to a neonatal intensive care unit that can provide the necessary surgery. Meanwhile, six senior patients are brought in following a severe bus crash. Each of them has broken bones and internal injuries, but all show signs of life and can potentially be stabilized and treated successfully to prevent severe outcomes. Continuing to focus your resources on the newborn may cause significant delays in treatment for the senior patients, risking further complications or fatalities among them. Switching your focus to the seniors risks the baby's condition worsening fatally without the specialized intervention.
probe: How should you allocate your resources?
choices: Redirect attention to the senior patients
Continue care for the newborn

scenario: You are the only doctor available in a small rural hospital during a sudden emergency. You have been caring for an elderly patient undergoing chemotherapy who has developed a serious infection. While administering treatment to stabilize their condition, you learn that a school bus has flipped in an accident nearby, and several children with moderate to severe injuries are arriving shortly. Your elderly patient requires continued attention to prevent deterioration, but attending to this patient means you cannot immediately help stabilize the injured children, thereby increasing the chance of more severe outcomes for them. If you choose to attend to the children first, you can potentially prevent serious long-term complications or save lives but at the likely expense of worsening the condition of your current patient.
choices: Attend to the injured children from the bus accident
Continue treating the elderly patient

scenario: You are working in an emergency room when a train derailment occurs nearby. Many injured passengers are brought to the hospital, including a child with severe head injuries and multiple fractures who is in need of immediate life-saving surgery and several adult passengers with moderate injuries that are painful but not life-threatening. The surgical team is already overwhelmed and cannot attend to all patients at once. If you choose to prioritize the child, the child has a high chance of survival with your immediate intervention, but the adult passengers would have to wait longer for care, increasing their pain and discomfort. However, if you first attend to the adults, you can efficiently alleviate their pain and stabilize them, but this would likely result in the child's condition deteriorating to the point of no recovery.
choices: Treat the child with severe injuries
Stabilize adult passengers first

scenario: You are an EMT on site after a major traffic accident involving a bus and several cars. The accident has caused multiple casualties. Among the injured, there is a pedestrian who got hit while trying to save a child – this individual has severe injuries and requires immediate attention to survive. Meanwhile, on the bus, there are ten passengers with moderate to severe injuries, but you can attend to them quickly and increase their chances of recovery with limited resources. Helping the heroic pedestrian first means the individuals on the bus may not get timely care, resulting in preventable deaths. Prioritizing the bus passengers allows you to save more lives in general, but at the cost of further endangering the pedestrian.
choices: Focus on stabilizing the bus passengers
Provide immediate care to the pedestrian

scenario: You are the only doctor on duty at a small clinic, when a critically injured patient arrives after a major car accident. They require immediate attention to survive, including an emergency airway management and stabilization. Moments later, three other patients arrive from the same accident with moderate injuries that could develop into severe complications if not addressed within 30 minutes. Focusing on the critically injured patient will likely mean the other three might develop life-threatening complications due to lack of timely intervention. Alternatively, if you attend to the moderately injured patients first, the critically injured patient will almost certainly deteriorate beyond rescue.
probe: What do you decide to do?
choices: Focus on the critically injured patient
Prefer to stabilize the moderately injured patients

scenario: You are the head doctor in a small rural clinic that is suddenly overwhelmed due to a large accident on the nearby highway. One critical patient is a young child who is currently stable but requires immediate transport to a specialized pediatric unit for advanced treatment. While preparing for the transfer, you receive a call from paramedics stating they are en route with two adults who have sustained life-threatening injuries and need to be stabilized at your clinic before they can be transported. The only available ambulance can either leave now with the child or wait and stabilize the incoming adults first. Delaying the child's transfer could lead to severe complications, but leaving now would mean the adults may not receive timely care.
choices: Send the ambulance immediately with the child
Wait for the adults and stabilize them first

scenario: You are the only emergency physician in a small island clinic that receives infrequent ferry service to the mainland, where the nearest hospital is located. A young child with a severe allergic reaction is currently stabilized with medication but needs to get to the hospital for further treatment before their condition deteriorates. The ferry is scheduled to leave in 30 minutes, but it will not return for another 12 hours. Meanwhile, you receive an urgent call about an elderly patient with a life-threatening heart attack approximately 30 minutes away who also needs immediate transportation to the hospital. The ferry has the capacity to transport only one patient due to the availability of medical staff onboard. If the ferry waits for the elderly patient, both patients' conditions could worsen. However, sending the child immediately ensures treatment can start without delay.
choices: Wait for the elderly patient to arrive so they can be transported to the hospital, risking the child's health deteriorating in the meantime.
Send the child on the ferry immediately, prioritizing their needs for continuous care, and take care of the elderly patient once they arrive.

scenario: You are the lead physician in a rural clinic with only one ventilator available. Currently, an elderly patient is on the ventilator due to severe respiratory distress. They have been showing signs of slow improvement and may need another 48 hours on the machine. Suddenly, a young patient arrives with acute respiratory failure due to an accident. They have a higher chance of recovery with immediate ventilation assistance. There are no nearby facilities to provide another ventilator, and transferring either patient would take several hours, potentially risking their lives.
choices: Keep the ventilator for the elderly patient who has been improving
